author: @Palteen87
text: This example is weird because chance of success is 49 against chance of loss of 51. He makes success from 51 to 99 (inclusive both) which gives 49 units, whereas loss equals from 1 to 50 which is 50 plus "100" which gives 51 in total

author: @sethrussell5470
text: While the initial videos are informative, the python code show here doesn't actually simulate what the author purports it is simulating. Hence this video and the next few videos show simulations that are incorrect. Take a look at other simulations of the Martingale strategy and you will see that the strategy will always loose.  One reason for this simulation being incorrect is that the bettor can bet more then they posses which cannot happen in real games of chance. Another error is that the person is only broke if they have < 0, meaning that in this simulation a bettor that has 0 dollars can place any bet for any amount as determined by their wager history. There are probably some other code errors, but since it is hard to copy exactly from the video, I can't post more specifics.
